title: Tariffs are taxes, and taxes are not political winners
text:
The only one-term president in the memory of most living Americans was the Republican who hiked people’s taxes.

Is President Trump looking to follow in his footsteps?

George H.W. Bush signed the income-tax hike that Democrats demanded, thus breaking his most famous campaign pledge: “Read my lips: No new taxes.” Had he resisted a tax increase, he might have fended off Bill Clinton and won a second term.

President Trump has increased taxes on imports — that is what tariffs are — unilaterally. Tariffs are not as economically destructive as income taxes are, and they are not as politically unpopular. But still, taxes impose a drag on the economy, and so if Trump loses in a close race, it’s entirely plausible that it will be his tariffs that drag him down.

So Trump is helping himself with his recent decision, as part of progress on a trade deal, to call off a planned tariff increase on $250 billion of exports. Trump ought to wrap up a deal as soon as possible and take down all the new tariffs he has imposed.

Trump’s tariffs are costing American households $425 a year, according to an estimate by the National Taxpayers Union Foundation. That’s not as bad as Bush’s 1990 tax hikes ($592 per household), and it’s also only an estimate based on economic models that may not bear out.

The tariffs, for instance, have not resulted in price increases yet. Also, in certain circumstances, the cost of the tariffs is not passed on to domestic consumers, but is instead born by foreign exporters. These complexities ought to instill tariff critics with some level of humility.

Yet tariffs are still taxes. Taxes, in general and all other things being equal, stultify commerce. In the long run, a country that allows more commerce to flow is wealthier than one that restricts commerce more.

If Trump’s tariffs were merely replacing other taxes, they might be fine. If Trump’s tariffs could bring back the heyday of U.S. manufacturing, there’s a strong case it would be worth costs to economic efficiency. We would take a slightly depressed GDP and more expensive jeans if it resulted in millions more good jobs for working-class men and women.

But that’s not happening. And if tariffs did bring manufacturing back home, the factories would be filled with robots rather than guys from Youngstown, Ohio.

Trump has done many good things for the economy. He has rolled back costly regulations. He has cut corporate taxes and individual income taxes. These things have made us wealthier as a people. Taxes will not make us wealthier — and they will not make Trump more popular.
